headline: Is Tesla Stock a Buy?
summary: Shares of Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) have been revving faster recently.  If you've been watching it from the sidelines, is now finally the time to buy Tesla stock?  By disrupting the automotive industry with its slick and technologically advanced EV models, Tesla has grown into one of the world's most valuable companies, currently sporting a market cap of $1.1 trillion.

headline: Weekend Tech Innovation Roundup November 30, 2024
summary: California Gov. Gavin Newsom is ruffling a lot of feathers — including Elon Musk’s — with his new proposal for electric vehicle incentives that would exclude Tesla’s (TSLA) popular models. - William Gavin Read More

headline: Tesla Stock Holds Near Highs Amid FSD News; Rival BYD Eyes BEV Crown
summary: Tesla is holding near two-year highs after Trump's election and with FSD v13 is coming. BYD has topped Tesla revenue and has eyes on the BEV crown.

headline: In the Desert With an EV Entrepreneur Who Insists Trump Will Be Good for Business
summary: JB Straubel brims with optimism for the electric-vehicle market he helped create and his plans for again disrupting another industry: mining.

headline: Up 38%, Is Tesla Stock a Buy?
summary: With shares up 38% since Nov. 5, Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) has been a huge beneficiary of Trump's presidential election victory.  CEO Elon Musk played a key role in the campaign, and many investors believe his company stands to benefit from the new economic and regulatory framework.

headline: Could Buying Rivian Stock Today Set You Up for Life?
summary: Rivian (NASDAQ: RIVN) hasn't had the best year in 2024.  In fact, the problems are more likely growing pains than anything else, given that the upstart electric vehicle (EV) company is focused squarely on reaching profitability as soon as possible.  Is Rivian following Tesla's lead?

headline: JPMorgan agrees to drop lawsuit against Tesla over stock warrants
summary: The move to drop the lawsuit was announced in a one-page court filing by both companies in a Manhattan court, where they said they will drop their claims against each other.  Neither company disclosed settlement terms, according to the court filings.  JPMorgan and Tesla did not immediately respond to Reuters' requests for comment.
